botanical_details.genus: Vaccinium can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs or small trees, with simple leaves and small, bell- or urn-shaped flowers followed by juicy, sometimes edible berries

how_to_grow.cultivation: Plant in a sheltered site in well-drained, moisture-retentive, acidic soil, (pH 4.5-5.5) in sun or part shade. Alternatively grow in containers or raised beds filled with ericaceous compost. Pot grown plants benefit from winter protection. For further cultivation details see blueberry cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings in late spring or semi-ripe cuttings in early summer
how_to_grow.pruning: More mature plants benefit from regular pruning, see blueberry pruning
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to vine weevil larvae damage especially if container grown. Protect ripening fruit with netting from birds.
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to powdery mildew and Phytophthora root rot. If grown in soil with pH higher than 5.5 chlorosis due to iron and manganese deficiency may be a problem – see nutrient deficiencies.
